title: Launceston City SC aims for Women Super League licence | The Examiner
body_text:
"We can't keep developing players and giving them to other teams, that's not happening anymore, we want a WSL licence."
Subscribe now for unlimited access.
or signup to continue reading
Launceston City Soccer Club president Danny Linger was passionate in his stance as his club announced their intention to re-apply for a Women's Super League licence on Friday.
After being knocked back last year in favour of fellow Northern Tasmanian side Riverside Olympic, the Prospect-based club are eager to even up the seven-team competition.
With City's pathway ending at Northern Championship, Linger estimated 10-12 players have gone elsewhere to play at the statewide level - something he does not want to see anymore.
"We think it's unfair that they've got to go to other clubs when they hit a brick wall and play WSL, they need to be playing here," he said.
"They don't want to move, we've got a good culture here, they want to stay here and play with their friends.
"The truth is the talented players that get to that level have no choice and that's not fair.
"We have players that go to nationals on the mainland with Tasmanian teams and do quite well, but to have them go to another club is heartbreaking."
If City were to get a licence, they would join Launceston United and Riverside Olympic in the top-flight competition.
When United joined the NPL men's competition last year, questions were raised about Northern Tasmania's ability to run three teams and Linger believes that will happen again.
"People will say, and it's a fair argument, can Launceston support three WSL teams and time will tell on that," he said.
"We can't just sit back and say 'go for it, we'll sit on the sidelines'. We can't keep developing players and giving them to other teams, that's not happening anymore, we want a WSL licence."
Running from under-5s through to their Northern Championships side, City have had a 200 per cent increase in female participation.
Describing themselves as the biggest junior club in the state, they have 600 juniors across 65 teams.
Linger confirmed the club intend to keep its women's Northern Championships side in operation should they enter the statewide competition.
The side are fourth on the six-team ladder this season, having won seven of their 19 games - improving on last year's result under new coaches.
"They've done a wonderful job, working right across the mental health and the diet to develop these girls and take the next step," he said.
"We are still about mid-table but we've got some talent that want to come back and play that are playing in other areas and we need to get this licence to give them that opportunity."
